learningContent.title: Adding topic references to a map

lcInstruction.p: The <topicref> element is structured as follows:

The href attribute contains a link to a topic that should be included in the map. In DITA, a map should not point to a topic that lives above it in your folder structure, so it is best to store your maps at the top level.Probably a better way to phrase this. Also, need to make sure we give users just enough here without getting too deep into folder structure/content management.
The <topicref> element may contain the following elements:

li.p: The <topicmeta> element, which defines metadata about the referenced topic.

lcInstruction.p: By nesting <topicref> or <mapref> elements inside of a <topicref> element, you can create a hierarchy in your map. This can make it easier for you to organize your topics. The hierarchy you create in the map's structure can also be reflected in a table of contents when the map is published.

When nesting <topicref> elements, it's important to keep your final output in mind. In DITA, there is no structural limit to the number of <topicref> elements that can be nested. However, each nested <topicref> will typically equate to a new heading level in your published output. Therefore, it is generally considered best practice to avoid nesting <topicref> elements more than five levels deep (and, ideally, no more than two or three).Probably also a better way to phrase this.

note.p: This lesson covers basic use of the <map> element and the map-level elements it contains. For the full specifications for each element, see the OASIS DITA Version 1.2 Standard.

step.cmd: After the <title> element, add a <topicref> element and add content to it as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE map PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Map//EN" "map.dtd"> <map id="ducks"> <title>Ducks</title> <topicref href="c_wild_ducks.dita"> </topicref> </map>

step.info: This <topicref> element creates a link to the concept topic c_wild_ducks.dita.

step.cmd: Inside the <topicref> element you just added, add another <topicref> element and add content to it as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE map PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Map//EN" "map.dtd"> <map id="ducks"> <title>Ducks</title> <topicref href="c_wild_ducks.dita"> <topicref href="c_wild_duck_types.dita"/> </topicref> </map>

step.info: By placing this <topicref> element inside the first one, you have nested the topic c_wild_duck_types.dita at the next level beneath c_wild_ducks.dita in the hierarchy of your map.

step.cmd: After the <topicref> element you just added, add two more <topicref> elements and add content to them as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE map PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Map//EN" "map.dtd"> <map id="ducks"> <title>Ducks</title> <topicref href="c_wild_ducks.dita"> <topicref href="c_wild_duck_types.dita"/> <topicref href="c_wild_duck_species.dita"/> <topicref href="t_watching_wild_ducks.dita"/> </topicref> </map>

step.info: These new <topicref> elements make the hierarchy in your DITA map even clearer. The topics c_wild_duck_types.dita, c_wild_duck_species.dita, and t_watching_wild_ducks.dita are related to each other because they pertain to wild ducks, and as such, they are nested under the topic c_wild_ducks.dita.

step.cmd: Add more <topicref> elements and add content to them as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE map PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Map//EN" "map.dtd"> <map id="ducks"> <title>Ducks</title> <topicref href="c_wild_ducks.dita"> <topicref href="c_wild_duck_types.dita"/> <topicref href="c_wild_duck_species.dita"/> <topicref href="t_watching_wild_ducks.dita"/> </topicref> <topicref href="c_domestic_ducks.dita"> <topicref href="c_duckling_growth.dita"/> <topicref href="c_feeding_ducklings.dita"> <topicref href="c_duck_weight.dita"/> </topicref> </topicref> <topicref href="c_duckdb.dita"> <topicref href="c_writing_about_ducks.dita" locktitle="yes"/> <topicref href="r_tnav.dita"/> </topicref> </map>

step.info: The map hierarchy now contains three first-level <topicref> elements: c_wild_ducks.dita, c_domestic_ducks.dita, and c_duckdb.dita. Each of these <topicref> elements contains nested second-level <topicref> elements. One of these second-level <topicref> elements, c_feeding_ducklings.dita, contains a nested third-level <topicref> element, c_duck_weight.dita.
